module.title: common nouns
module.p: Common nouns are nouns which refer to a class of entities and may be used when referring to instances of that specific class.
Common nouns can be classified into different semantic types, depending on the kind of entity they describe –

ul.li:
Anthropological common nouns refer to categories of human being –
Ethnonymic common nouns classify people according to ethno-cultural heritage eg. Gàidheal Gael, Cruithneach Pict, Leòdhasach person from Lewis, Lochlannach a Scandinavian, Frisealach member of the Fraser clan, Caimbeulach a Campbell.
Professional common nouns classify people according to their job or social status eg. saor carpenter, sagart priest, gobha metalsmith, rìgh king, ceannard chief.
Other anthropological common classify people according to their sex and/or age, eg. cailleach old woman, bodach old man, bean woman, fear man, caileag girl, balach boy, paiste child, leanabh baby.
Anthropological aggregate common nouns refer to non-bounded pluralities of people eg. clann children, muinntir people, luchd people.
Anthropological collective common nouns refer to bounded groups of people eg. sgioba team, buidheann group, comataidh committee, bòrd board.
Zoological common nouns refer to categories of animal.
